definitions.definition: polite behaviour that shows respect for other people

examples.text: I was treated with the utmost courtesy by the staff.
We asked them, **as a matter of courtesy**, if we could photograph their house.
It's only **common courtesy** to tell the neighbours that we'll be having a party *(= the sort of behaviour that people would expect)*.
He listened to all the complaints with great courtesy.
It's a matter of courtesy to write and thank people after a party.
It's common courtesy to warn your neighbours if your children are going to have a party.
She contacts clients regularly as a professional courtesy.
He bowed his head with exaggerated courtesy.
We asked them as a matter of courtesy.

definitions.definition: a polite thing that you say or do when you meet people in formal situations

examples.text: an exchange of courtesies before the meeting
The prime minister was welcomed with the usual courtesies.

definitions.definition: with the official permission of somebody/something and as a favour

examples.text: The pictures have been reproduced by courtesy of the British Museum.

definitions.definition: given as a prize or provided free by a person or an organization

examples.text: Win a weekend in Rome, courtesy of Fiat.

definitions.definition: as the result of a particular thing or situation

examples.text: Viewers can see the stadium from the air, courtesy of a camera fastened to the plane.

definitions.definition: to be polite by doing the thing that is mentioned

examples.text: Please do me the courtesy of listening to what I'm saying.
She might have done me the courtesy of replying to my letter.

definitions.definition: to know when you should do something in order to be polite

examples.text: You think he'd at least have the courtesy to call to say he'd be late.
You could at least have had the courtesy to let me know.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French cortesie, from corteis, based on Latin cohors ‘yard, retinue’.
